channel.title: PSAT/SAT scores
channel.description:
Just curious as to what users on this site scored on their PSAT/SAT. I haven't taken my SAT yet, but my PSAT scores are as follows. Critical Reading - 47 Math - 70 Writing - 59
So an overall score of 176. Hoping to get ~2000 on the final SAT. Got a lot of work to do in English. :P
Also ITT where you want to go to college/college currently attending/college(s) you have attended. I personally want to go to MIT, but probably won't because they are so selective and you need at least a 2000 on your SAT and a composite of 32 on your ACT to get a decent chance of being admitted. My backup plan is to go to Purdue for 4 years then maybe go to MIT for 2 years and get my master in CS.

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“baddy351, post:47, topic:429084”]I know my parents, I havn’t taken mine.
My mom got a 2390 and my dad got a 2270.
my mom almost had a perfect one.[/quote]
I was too lazy to take it a second time. I would have gotten a perfect score if I did, haha.

[quote=“Davidi2, post:48, topic:429084”][quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=531775.msg3889504#msg3889504 date=1326729324]

Sadly my school doesn’t offer many college courses. Best they get is dual credit for taking Calculus as a senior. And I also <3 math because it has never been difficult for me. I just make little mistakes that make me facepalm once I go over which questions I got wrong. Like on the PSAT I was pretty confident I was going to get a near perfect score, but I managed to make stupid mistakes on two of the easy level math questions. Just kind of curious, how is the time frame on the actual SAT? I know that I didn’t have much leftover time on the PSAT. It was about 30 mins for 40 questions iirc.

I finished each section in under 15 minutes. Then again, I didn’t really try, haha…
[/quote]Sounds kinda like the WASL here, we’re given 2 hours to do each section (Math, Science, Reading, and Writing), spread out over 4 days, and I did each in less than 15-30. Thank God they let us bring books to read when we were done, I went through the first half of the Harry Potter series that week lol. Then when I went to sign up for the online HS the next year, she said I had the ‘highest reading WASL score’ she had ever seen XD[/quote]
Haha, nice. That’s awesome. I have a bunch of Asians at my school, so my perfect scores were impressive, but nothing out of the ordinary. xD

Read full topic

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @MistaBigBoss MistaBigBoss
item.description:
@MistaBigBoss wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:50, topic:429084”]The SAT Reasoning Test is a standardized test for college admissions in the United States. The SAT is owned, published, and developed by the College Board, a nonprofit organization in the United States. It was formerly developed, published, and scored by the Educational Testing Service[1] which still administers the exam. The test is intended to assess a student’s readiness for college. It was first introduced in 1926, and its name and scoring have changed several times. It was first called the Scholastic Aptitude Test, then the Scholastic Assessment Test, but now SAT does not stand for anything, hence is an empty acronym.

The current SAT Reasoning Test, introduced in 2005, takes three hours and forty-five minutes to finish, and costs $49 ($75 International), excluding late fees.[2] Possible scores range from 600 to 2400, combining test results from three 800-point sections (Mathematics, Critical Reading, and Writing).

Taking the SAT or its competitor, the ACT, is required for freshman entry to many, but not all, universities in the United States.[3]

Straight from wikipedia. The PSAT is just the pre-sat, like a practice test.[/quote]Thanks, sorry for my lazyness.

Read full topic

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

The SAT Reasoning Test is a standardized test for college admissions in the United States. The SAT is owned, published, and developed by the College Board, a nonprofit organization in the United States. It was formerly developed, published, and scored by the Educational Testing Service[1] which still administers the exam. The test is intended to assess a student’s readiness for college. It was first introduced in 1926, and its name and scoring have changed several times. It was first called the Scholastic Aptitude Test, then the Scholastic Assessment Test, but now SAT does not stand for anything, hence is an empty acronym.

The current SAT Reasoning Test, introduced in 2005, takes three hours and forty-five minutes to finish, and costs $49 ($75 International), excluding late fees.[2] Possible scores range from 600 to 2400, combining test results from three 800-point sections (Mathematics, Critical Reading, and Writing).

Taking the SAT or its competitor, the ACT, is required for freshman entry to many, but not all, universities in the United States.[3]

Straight from wikipedia. The PSAT is just the pre-sat, like a practice test.

Read full topic

item.description:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:46, topic:429084”][quote author=The Wanderer link=topic=531775.msg3889255#msg3889255 date=1326691270]
Sadly my school doesn’t offer many college courses. Best they get is dual credit for taking Calculus as a senior. And I also <3 math because it has never been difficult for me. I just make little mistakes that make me facepalm once I go over which questions I got wrong. Like on the PSAT I was pretty confident I was going to get a near perfect score, but I managed to make stupid mistakes on two of the easy level math questions. Just kind of curious, how is the time frame on the actual SAT? I know that I didn’t have much leftover time on the PSAT. It was about 30 mins for 40 questions iirc.
[/quote]
I finished each section in under 15 minutes. Then again, I didn’t really try, haha…[/quote]Sounds kinda like the WASL here, we’re given 2 hours to do each section (Math, Science, Reading, and Writing), spread out over 4 days, and I did each in less than 15-30. Thank God they let us bring books to read when we were done, I went through the first half of the Harry Potter series that week lol. Then when I went to sign up for the online HS the next year, she said I had the ‘highest reading WASL score’ she had ever seen XD

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

The Wanderer:

Sadly my school doesn’t offer many college courses. Best they get is dual credit for taking Calculus as a senior. And I also <3 math because it has never been difficult for me. I just make little mistakes that make me facepalm once I go over which questions I got wrong. Like on the PSAT I was pretty confident I was going to get a near perfect score, but I managed to make stupid mistakes on two of the easy level math questions. Just kind of curious, how is the time frame on the actual SAT? I know that I didn’t have much leftover time on the PSAT. It was about 30 mins for 40 questions iirc.

I finished each section in under 15 minutes. Then again, I didn’t really try, haha…

[quote=“Davidi2, post:42, topic:429084”]My college level classes aren’t through a high school, it’s through a college, then THEY go through the high school to get me credit there too

Though there are things that go the other way around like yours (I actually got like 15 college credits in my Freshman high school year, which was basically like a full quarter of college), including calculus, but I skipped it in HS to take it in college, as it’s much faster there.[/quote]
Lucky, we weren’t allowed to do that.

Read full topic

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:26, topic:429084”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=531775.msg3887519#msg3887519 date=1326575688]
I have no idea what a SAT is but I’m going for my interview for http://www.stevenson.ac.uk/courses/course/degree-foundation-computing-course/?fs=1

‘On successful completion, students can progress onto HND Computer Games Development, or other computing discipline, or to Degree level courses at university.’
[MG]http://img51.imageshack.us/img51/4936/img00869201201121836.jpg[/img]

I’ll have my first Diploma before I even turn 18 :D, assuming I pass etc
[/quote]Sounds somewhat like what I’m doing, except instead of getting the diploma before the degree, you start getting credit for both from doing the college classes. Like right now I’m taking three college classes, and each quarter counts as a whole year of HS credit. So basically every class you pass (2-3 months) counts for 5 college credits (and a typical 2 year degree is 90 credits here, 5 credits x 3 classes x 3 quarters x 2 years), and 1 HS credit (which is the equivalent of 2 semesters (10 months))[/quote]
Ah very nice :D, hope you do well in this btw but I know you probably will haha. Ah sounds good. This is a pretty fast track course, a five month course I believe so I hope I do well :P, gonna be horrible with muuch older people though, like atm I’m with mostly 20 to late 20s but this is not a course you typically see young people doing and I’m really social so it’d be horrible for me not to be social and have friends I’d see out of the class and I can be pretty immature at times:L.

Its a shame yous get charged for your education(in college)! Here in Scotland we actually get paid once you turn sixteen and are in full-time education(something like $50p/w + travelling monthly+ extra costs p/w if you want it which can be up to $1600p/m in some cases, any other types of course like part-time you get charged for) and we get lots of benefits like tax reductions etc for being a Student. The same goes with Universities, and people wonder why I love Scotland so much haha.

Read full topic

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Yea, here you need to be a Junior to do it

It’s called Running Start here in Washington, it’s state by state, so I don’t know if yours has it (and if it did, it would be under a different name).

Basically you go to real college, take real college classes, etc, except it’s funded by the state (basically a two year scholarship) and your college classes count for high school credit too.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

Ah. How exactly would you go about doing that, then? I thought you had to do it through your high school haha. Will definitely be interested in doing that next year as a Junior.

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

My college level classes aren’t through a high school, it’s through a college, then THEY go through the high school to get me credit there too

Though there are things that go the other way around like yours (I actually got like 15 college credits in my Freshman high school year, which was basically like a full quarter of college), including calculus, but I skipped it in HS to take it in college, as it’s much faster there.

Read full topic

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:38, topic:429084”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=531775.msg3888781#msg3888781 date=1326678884]

Here, the ‘full load’ is 3 classes, with 4 ‘pushing it’

I dunno how that’s set up… do you go to all 6 classes every day? Is there a lot of HW? We’re supposed to go to school 3/4 hours a day and then have 2 hours of homework for every class, so I don’t see how that’d be possible with 6 Then again it seems your credit system is different here, almost all classes are 5 credits here

Wait, are you talking about an actual college or courses you’re taking?

I don’t go to all 6 classes each day. I have around 3-4 classes each day next semester and 1 on Friday (woo!). We get a ton of HW, especially the honors classes, and I always seem to put it off until last minute. ><
[/quote]I go to college, and those are the courses I’m taking.

When you register, they say ‘3 daily classes’ (15 credits total) is a full load for a quarter. So it sounds similar to yours.

Sounds very similar. How old are you and what are you taking? I wish I had the opportunity to take college courses when I was 14ish. :([/quote]Oh I thought I said it earlier… but I’m taking Sociology 1, Philosophy 1, and English right now (only because I need to for the basic BAS prereqs… my degree is software design) . I took IT101, Calculus 1, and Research English last quarter. And my age is on my profile

Read full topic

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

[quote=“Davidi2, post:30, topic:429084”]You guys go on semesters there? So do you take 3 classes a quarter or what? 6 classes seems like a lot to be taking at one time at least, not sure how it’s set up…

And what is your major? That’s a lot of math classes. I personally hate high-level math, even if it isn’t difficult… I just don’t see the point with what I’m interested in :P[/quote]

We take as many courses as we want. For regular students, the limit is 18 credits, which is 4-5 classes. I’m taking 6 classes totaling 21 credits and that’s allowed for honors students.

And yes, haha. I’m going to be a math major! I <3 math. Last semester and this coming semester were and are going to be easy, but next year will get a bit harder once I get to Number Theory, etc, but I will probably still enjoy the classes… I don’t think what I’m taking next semester is high-level math; I’m not sure, lol. I know that I’ll be in class with a lot of juniors and seniors as a freshman though. ><

There’s 2 semesters in a school year (well, duhh, ‘semestris’ haha)… My break ends tomorrow though. <|3

Read full topic

item.title: PSAT/SAT scores
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

You guys go on semesters there? So do you take 3 classes a quarter or what? 6 classes seems like a lot to be taking at one time at least, not sure how it’s set up…

And what is your major? That’s a lot of math classes. I personally hate high-level math, even if it isn’t difficult… I just don’t see the point with what I’m interested in

Read full topic
